text: I had the opportunity to teach Antonio
Grahamshy yesterday for my class on 20th
century Marxist philosophy and I want to
share one of the things that I consider
to be most important from his prison
notebook. None of the classics of
Marxism either Marx angles or Lenin ever
really sat down and wrote a refined text
about the Marxist understanding of
ideology. There's some comments in the
early German ideology uh that Marks and
Engles wrote and in some of the old
letters from Engles that suggest an
epistemological understanding of
ideology. So ideology as a form of
distorted or false consciousness as a
way of inverting the world and placing
it on its head. And then there's also a
bunch of comments about ideology in a
functionalist sense. So how ideas
corresponding to various classes play
different social functions for the
dominant order. Both understandings of
ideology are scattered all throughout
the classics. So Markx, Engles, and
Lenin. However, given that neither of
them was ever able to sit down and just
produce one refined, well-edited and
published text on the subject, the
different senses in which ideology has
been used has been caused for debate in
Marxist scholarship. And there's
generally two camps. Those who look at
ideology in a functionalist sense, so
ideology as the different functions that
collections of ideas and institutions
play for society, and those who look at
it in an epistemological sense. So the
way in which ideology is a way to
distort how it is that we view the
world. Ramsey of course falls more
towards the functionalist side of things
and his focus as someone who is leading
the communist party of Italy and who is
trying to figure out the best ways to
think and defeat Mussolini's fascism was
how could communists win people over?
How can you convince them? And for him,
central to this enterprise is realizing
that you can't just dismiss the views
that people have. The worldview that
people have, whether it's a very
backwards form of what he called
folklore or religion or common sense,
all of which belong to what he called
the ideological orders. You can't just
dismiss those. You have to realize that
there's a rational kernel. Uh in common
sense, he called it a good sense
nucleus. There's something in there that
is rational, that is true. And your job
as an organizer as a communist is to
identify that rational kernel to
disarticulate it from the predominant
worldview in which it is in and to begin
the process of nurturing it so that you
could rearticulate it so towards a
socialist class consciousness. This is
why scholars like Peter Thomas call
Antonio Gracy the theorists of the
intellectuals par excellence because he
sees that intellectuals specifically
organic dissident intellectuals which
are not just people working in the
academy. Those are the traditional
intellectuals. He sees the fundamental
task of the socialist intellectual as
one of winning the war of positions the
battle of ideas the uh battle and the
ideological terrain for the consent of
the working masses of the subaltering
classes in general. And you can only do
this if you're able to connect to the
people. If you look down on the people
condescendingly, as large parts of the
primarily middle class uh PMC, preACP
left in the US did where they considered
the American working class to be too
provincial and backwards to even attempt
organizing. you're obviously not going
to be able to build counter hijgemony,
to build working-class hijgemony, to
position yourself as a leading force for
the working-class movement that can
bring them away from this sort of trade
union consciousness and towards an
actual socialist class consciousness.
And for Grahamshy, central for this task
was not just identifying that good sense
nucleus in their thinking, but also
doing the same thing at the ethical
political level. So at the level of
their affects, at the level of their
desires, at the level of their passions.
So it's about identifying not just what
ideas people already hold that
implicitly could be developed into an
explicit form of socialist class
consciousness, but what sort of
sentiments, what sort of emotions, what
sort of passions, what sort of desires
do they hold that we can do the same
thing with. This is why for me, you
know, Grahamshy is uh the Grahamshy that
I, you know, adhere to is not the one
that's taught in the Western Academy,
the one that's used in all these uh
basically neoliberal postcolonial
studies. The gramy that I adhere to was
a Marxist Leninist that was trying to
figure out concretely what is the best
way for communist organizers to win over
the working class. Why did the
revolutions that were supposed to spread
across Western Europe fail? And how do
we focus on the war of position, the
battle of ideas, so that we can actually
win for ourselves a socialist world? And
I think that if there is a thinker today
that we must actually study directly, it
is Antonio Gracie. If you're interested
in reading more about this, I wrote a
very in-depth chapter on the subject of
Grahamshy intellectuals ideology and
the ethical political for the Elgar's
anthology on Antonio Grahamshy from I
believe last year or the year before
that. So if you look up my name and you
look up Grahamshy, you should be able to
find
